description: A global financial services company moved their North American headquarters to a new location with over 1.1 million square feet of space. As a modern and world-class workplace, the client's goal was to showcase its culture and positive impact through thoughtful digital touchpoints throughout their North American Headquarters. We developed a holistic digital strategy that resulted in the execution of a series of digital interventions – both expressive and functional – throughout the campus to add brand and business value, and elevate the employee and visitor experience.

The activations include the Sky Lobby Reception installation, a 30-foot-long dynamic digital art piece, swashes of color emanating from behind a metal facade covered in letter cutouts. Hidden amongst the letters names and dates important to the client provide moments of discovery. The Media Pillars, large imposing vertical LED screens displaying artful branded generative content in the lobby, providing visitors with a welcome moment. Finally, we designed a cohesive digital signage system with a variety of templates designed with their brand guidelines and integrated with their digital signage system.

description: The Impact of the Bible floor is 30,000 square feet of permanent galleries for the Museum of the Bible, dubbed the most technologically advanced museum in the world. The galleries examine the cultural and historical influence of the most read, most loved, most hated book in the world.

Perhaps the most unexpected gallery on that floor is, “Bible Now.” The gallery explores the impact of the Bible in real-time. A 360-degree, full height, constantly changing panorama of digital information shows the Bible’s impact in actual time. The immersive digital experience is sourced from multiple channels. Live information is streamed from social media feeds around the world, readings of tens of millions of Bible app users, a 24-hour time-lapse view of the biblical city of Jerusalem, and current contributions by museum visitors on the three interactive tables, allowing visitors to express their creativity in real-time.

description: The Photography Interpretive Gallery at SFMOMA serves as an exhibition space, educational center, and gathering place, inviting visitors to discover, learn, create, and reflect. Designed by Second Story, the gallery seamlessly blends digital and physical elements to create an experience that is both familiar and unexpected. Through interactive installations, visitors are encouraged to engage critically with photography—examining how images shape our perceptions and the stories they tell.

Three key installations bring this concept to life. The View from Here explores photography’s role in shaping California’s history and mythology, allowing visitors to navigate narratives using dials reminiscent of a camera’s mechanics. In Their Own Words delves into the diverse creative processes of contemporary photographers, offering themed video playlists with candid artist interviews, enhanced by a seamlessly integrated speaker array. Self Composed, developed in collaboration with Adobe, invites visitors to create self-representations using only the contents of their pockets, prompting reflection on how images define identity. Together, these installations transform the gallery into an immersive space for exploration and discovery.

description: The Records of Rights exhibit at the National Archives’ David M. Rubenstein Gallery explores America’s ongoing struggle for freedom through historic documents, images, and videos. Encouraging dialogue, the table lets users tag records with emotional reactions, which appear on nearby wall monitors to spark discussion. An accompanying online exhibition extends access beyond the gallery, enabling exploration from anywhere in the world.
